original: Yadi, bhante nāgasena, bodhisatto tiracchānagato samāno kāsāvaṁ abhipūjayi, tena🔽hi ‘jotipālena māṇavena kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho muṇḍakavādena samaṇakavādena

translated: If the Bodhisatta, when he was an animal, honoured the yellow robe,🔽then it is not true that the young brāhman Jotipāla abused and reviled the Blessed One Kassapa, accomplished and fully enlightened, with the words ‘bald-pate’ and ‘degenerate ascetic,’

translated: then the statement ‘the Nāga king Chaddanta worshipped the yellow robe’ is false.

original: Yadi tiracchānagatena bodhisattena kakkhaḷakharakaṭukavedanaṁ vedayamānena luddakena
analyzed: yadi tiracchāna gatena bodhisattena kakkhaḷa khara kaṭuka vedanam vedayamānena luddakena
translated: If the Bodhisatta, an animal, who was experiencing painful, sharp, severe, and harsh feelings, worshipped the yellow robe that had been cast off by the hunter,🔽then why, being a human being, with his knowledge mature, with his enlightenment mature,

translated: did he not worship the Lord Buddha Kassapa, the Worthy One, the Perfectly Enlightened One, the One of Ten Powers, the Leader of the World, the Incomparable Charioteer of men to be tamed, the Teacher of gods and men, the Buddha, the Lord, who was resplendent with the radiance of the thirty-two marks of a great man,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the eighty minor marks,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the fathom-wide aura,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the ten powers,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the four grounds of self-confidence,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the seven factors of enlightenment,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the eightfold path,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the six super-knowledges,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the four foundations of mindfulness,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the four right efforts,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the four bases of spiritual success,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the five spiritual faculties,

original: kassapaṁ bhagavantaṁ arahantaṁ sammāsambuddhaṁ dasabalaṁ lokanāyakaṁ uditoditaṁ jalitabyāmobhāsaṁ
analyzed: kassapam bhagavantam arahantam sammāsambuddham dasabalam lokanāyakam uditoditam jalita byāma ubhāsa

translated: who was resplendent with the radiance of the five higher knowledges,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the six super-knowledges,🔽who was resplendent with the radiance of the four foundations of mindfulness,

analyzed: mahā rāja bhagavatā chaddantaḥ nāga rājā pe
translated: who was resplendent with the radiance of

original: Jotipālena ca māṇavena kassapo bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho muṇḍakavādena samaṇakavādena asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkuṭṭho paribhāsito, tañca pana jātivasena kulavasena.
analyzed: jotipālena ca māṇavena kassapaḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ muṇḍaka vādena samaṇaka vādena asabbhāhi pharusāhi vācāhi akkuṭṭhaḥ paribhāsitaḥ tat ca pana jāti vasena kula vasena
translated: And the young brāhmaṇa Jotipāla, with the words ‘shaveling,’ ‘monk,’ ‘lowly,’ and ‘vile,’ reviled, abused, and censured the Fortunate One Kassapa, the Worthy One, the Perfect Sambuddha, and he did so on the basis of his birth and his family.

original: Jotipālo, mahārāja, māṇavo assaddhe appasanne kule paccājāto, tassa mātāpitaro bhaginibhātaro
analyzed: jotipālaḥ mahā rāja māṇavaḥ assaddhe appasanne kule paccājātaḥ tassa mātā pitaraḥ bhagini bhātaro
translated: The young brāhmaṇa Jotipāla, Great King, was born in a family that was without faith and without confidence, and his mother and father, his brothers and sisters,

original: dāsidāsaceṭakaparivārakamanussā brahmadevatā brahmagarukā, te ‘brāhmaṇā eva uttamā
analyzed: dāsi dāsa ceṭaka parivāraka manussāḥ brahmadevatāḥ brahmagarukā te brāhmaṇāḥ eva uttamā
translated: his female and male slaves, his female and male servants, his messengers, his relatives, his friends and companions, his acquaintances, his brāhmaṇas, his gods, his teachers, and his preceptors were also without faith and without confidence, and they said: ‘Only brāhmaṇas are the highest caste,

original: pavarā’ti avasese pabbajite garahanti jigucchanti, tesaṁ taṁ vacanaṁ sutvā jotipālo
analyzed: avasese pabbajite garahanti jigucchanti tesam tam vacanam sutvā jotipālo

analyzed: māṇavaḥ ghaṭikārena kumbhakārena satthāram dassanāya pakkositaḥ evam āha
translated: when he was invited by Ghaṭīkāra the potter to see the Teacher, said:

original: ‘kiṁ pana tena muṇḍakena samaṇakena diṭṭhenā’ti.
analyzed: kim pana tena muṇḍakena samaṇakena diṭṭhena ati
translated: ‘What is the use of seeing that shaveling monk?’

original: Yathā, mahārāja, amataṁ visamāsajja tittakaṁ hoti, yathā ca sītodakaṁ aggimāsajja uṇhaṁ hoti;
analyzed: yathā mahā rāja amatam visamāsajja tittakam hoti yathā ca sītā udakam aggim āsajja uṇham hoti
translated: Just as, Great King, nectar becomes bitter when it is mixed with poison, and just as cold water becomes hot when it is near fire;

translated: Even so, sire, the young brāhman Jotipāla was born in a family that was without faith and without confidence. He was blind through the fault of that family and reviled and abused the Tathāgata.

original: Yathā, mahārāja, jalitapajjalito mahāaggikkhandho sappabhāso udakamāsajja upahatappabhātejo sītalo kāḷako bhavati paripakkanigguṇḍiphalasadiso;

analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja jotipālaḥ māṇavaḥ puññavā saddhaḥ ñāṇa vipula sa pabhāsaḥ assaddhe
translated: even so, sire, the young brāhman Jotipāla, who was endowed with merit, who was faithful, who was bright with the radiance of knowledge,

original: appasanne kule paccājāto, so kulavasena andho hutvā tathāgataṁ akkosi paribhāsi,
analyzed: appasanne kule paccājāto saḥ kula vasena andhaḥ hutvā tathāgatam akkosi paribhāsi
translated: was born in a family that was without faith and without confidence. He was blind through the fault of that family and reviled and abused the Tathāgata.

analyzed: upagantvā ca buddha guṇam aññāya ceṭaka bhūtaḥ viya ahosi jina sāsane pabbajitvā abhiññā
translated: But when he had approached and had understood the qualities of the Buddha, he became like a servant and, having gone forth in the Dispensation of the Conqueror, he produced the kinds of direct-knowledge

translated: “Excellent, revered Nāgasena; so it is, therefore do I accept this statement.”
